page.title: 05WILDLIFE ON RACK ISLE,BIBURY
page.content: Rack Isle is a National Trust Wildfowl Reserve that lies in the centre of Bibury and is almost surrounded by water.Most of the river birds nest on the Isle especially Mallards,Coots and Moorhens.It is the home of many wetland creatures and plants. The river banks are inhabited by water voles and moles. The marshy areas have toads, frogs and snakes. Several species of wetland plants are found on Rack Isle. The most obvious are the flowering plants like Marsh Marigolds, Ragged Robin, Meadow Sweet, Yellow Iris, Monkey Flower and Comfrey, but other plants are more inconspicuous like the grasses, sedges, bullrushes and butterbur. Recently, more trees have been planted, particularly poplar and willow. Rack Isle's name dates from when it was used for drying the cloth used in Arlington Mill.
